title: What's the difference between doctoral and PhD titles? - Quora

response.answer_text: A doctorate or doctoral degree is the highest degree granted in an academic discipline, also called a terminal degree.  Examples include doctor of philosophy (Ph.D. or D.Phil.), doctor of science (Sc.D.), and doctor of education (Ed.D.). These are research degrees and usually involve writing and defending a doctoral thesis. Other examples involve professional degrees, such as juris doctor (J.D.), doctor of medicine (M.D.), doctor of osteopathic medicine (D.O.), doctor of optometry (O.D.), doctor of veterinary medicine (D.V.M.), doctor of dental surgery (D.D.S.) and doctor of pharmacy (Pharm.D.). These do not necessarily involve a research component or a doctoral thesis. Recipients of any of these degrees may use the honorific "Dr." as a prefix to their name, but many will instead use the abbreviation specific to their degree as a suffix.

Doctoral degrees exist for many professions but my lay not be PhDs.PhDs are doctors of philosophy with an emphasis on research or thesis that is unique to the specific PhD.for example a PhD in education would be awarded after necessary class work and a thesis regarding some educational framework is done and defended.Other doctorates exist for entry level criteria for positions:MD - MEDICAL doctorateDPT - doctorate of physical therapyDPMDScDCDOJDThese will have a bend towards research in the programs but typically have a focus on clinical/professional excellence.

PhD is a degree given after formalized education including research into a new knowledge in that field of study, whereas a professional doctorate is given to an expert in the field who have taken existing knowledge to find newer applications, to solve real world problems, technical social economic etc.
